Man admits 'honour killing' of his sister
 By A Correspondent
 
 
 
 THE youngest of three Turkish brothers charged with murdering their sister in a so-called honour killing has admitted that he pulled the trigger, but as the trial opened in a Berlin state court yesterday he insisted that he acted alone. 
 Hatun Surucu, 25, was killed in February by three shots to the head on a street near her home. The case outraged Germans and brought to light the honour killings and forced marriages among the nation's Turkish population. 
 
 
 
 According to prosecutors, Ms Surucu's brothers lured her to a bus stop with the intent of killing her because they were ashamed of her Western lifestyle. "I killed my sister," Ayhan Surucu, 19, said in a statement read by his lawyer. He said that he regretted the act and insisted that his two older brothers were not involved. 
 
 Mutlu Surucu, 26, who has German citizenship, and Alpaslan Surucu, 24, a Turkish citizen, as is his younger brother, pleaded not guilty. All three face charges of second-degree murder. 
 
 Hatun was a German citizen, born and brought up in Berlin, but was forced to return to Turkey to marry a cousin in 1998. A year later she gave birth to a son in Berlin and refused to return with her husband to Turkey, prosecutors said.
